case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee

facts.text: This is a group of 15 appeals by Life Insurance Corporation of India against orders quashing termination of services of 15 employees.

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, J. This is a group of 15 appeals which raise a common question about the validity of the orders passed by the appellant Life Insurance Corporation of India terminating the services of its employees who are the respondents in these appeals.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee was in the insurance line since June 1941.

anchor.surface_text: One of the respondents is Sunil Kumar Mukherjee. He was in the insurance line since June, 1941 and had been confirmed in his service by the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. in March, 1950.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee confirmed in service by Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. in March 1950.

anchor.surface_text: One of the respondents is Sunil Kumar Mukherjee. He was in the insurance line since June, 1941 and had been confirmed in his service by the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. in March, 1950.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee working as Inspector since about 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Since about 1953, he had been working as Inspector of the said Company, and since March 18, 1955, he was holding the appointment as Inspector at Barrackpore.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee appointed Inspector at Barrackpore on March 18, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Since about 1953, he had been working as Inspector of the said Company, and since March 18, 1955, he was holding the appointment as Inspector at Barrackpore.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation terminated services of Sunil Kumar Mukherjee on October 16, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant which took over the controlled business of the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd., terminated the services of Mukherjee by an order passed on the 16th October, 1958.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Calcutta High Court seeking certiorari to quash termination order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the Calcutta High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and prayed for a writ of certiorari or other appropriate writ or order quashing the said impugned order of discharge passed against him.

facts.text: Sinha J. allowed the writ petition and issued certiorari and mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: Sinha J. who heard the writ petition, allowed the petition and directed that a writ in the nature of certiorari quashing and or setting aside the impugned order be issued. A further writ in the nature of mandamus was also issued directing the respondents to the writ petition

facts.text: LIC appealed to Division Bench of Calcutta High Court under Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of Sinha J. the appellants preferred an appeal under the Letters Patent before a Division Bench of the said High Court Bose C.J. and Debabrata Mokerjee J. who heard the Letters Patent appeal substantially agreed with the view taken by Sinha J.

facts.text: Division Bench confirmed Sinha J.'s order.

anchor.surface_text: Bose C.J. and Debabrata Mokerjee J. who heard the Letters Patent appeal substantially agreed with the view taken by Sinha J. and confirmed the order passed by him.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained a certificate of fitness from the said High Court and it is with the said certificate that they have come to this Court in appeal.

facts.text: Mukherjee appointed whole-time Inspector by Metropolitan on March 18 or 19, 1955 with terms in 14 clauses document.

anchor.surface_text: When Mr. Mukherjee was appointed a whole-time Inspector by the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. on the 18th or 19th March, 1955, the terms and conditions of his employment were communicated to him by a document which contained 14 clauses (Annexure A to the W.P.).

facts.text: Clause 13 allowed termination without notice for misconduct, 30 days notice otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 13 of this document provided that the appointment was subject to termination without notice in case he was found guilty of fraud, mis-appropriation, breach of discipline, insubordination, acting detrimental to the interests of the company, disloyalty or gross neglect of duty provided, however, that he would be entitled to 30 days notice if his services were terminated for any other reason.

facts.text: Order dated February 14, 1958 required Mukherjee to work as Field Officer attached to Barrackpore.

anchor.surface_text: When the Life Insurance Corpn. took over the business of the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd., an order was issued in favour of Mr. Mukherjee on the 14th February, 1958. By this order it was stated that in terms of Government Order No. 53(1)/I.S.N.(1)/57 dated 30th December, 1957, he was required to work as a Field Officer.

facts.text: Termination order October 16, 1958 based on section 5 of Categorisation circular December 2, 1957 and Special Committee recommendation.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th October, 1958, the impugned order terminating Mr. Mukherjees services was passed. This order said that in terms of section 5 of the Categorisation circular of the 2nd December, 1957, Mr. Mukherjees case was examined by the Special Committee appointed by the Board of the Corporation to review the cases of Ex-Branch Secretaries, etc.,

facts.text: Life Insurance (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance No. 1 of 1956 promulgated on January 19, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The history of the nationalisation of the Life Insurance business in this country is well-known. On the 19th January, 1956, the Life Insurance (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance No. 1 of 1956 was promulgated by the President

facts.text: Act No. 9 of 1956 came into effect on March 21, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In due course, Act No. 9 of 1956 was passed which took the place of the original Ordinance and it came into effect on the 21st March, 1956.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation Act 31 of 1956 published July 1, 1956, appointed day September 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This Act was followed by Act 31 of 1956 (hereinafter called the Act) which was published on the 1st July, 1956. The appointed date under s. 3 of this Act was the 1st of September, 1956.

facts.text: Central Government order dated December 30, 1957 under s.11(2) known as blue order for Field Officers.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th December, 1957, an order was issued by the Central Government in exercise of the powers conferred on it by s. 11(2) of the Act. This order was issued on blue paper and has been described by the High Court as the blue order.

facts.text: No enquiry held before termination and not under clause 10(b).

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that before terminating the services of the respective respondents in the group of appeals before us, no enquiry has been held and no opportunity has been given to the said officers as required by clause 10(a) of the Order.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds termination orders invalid for non-compliance with clause 10 of the Order.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already seen, it is common ground that the impugned orders terminating the services of the respective respondents have not been passed in accordance either with clause 10(a) or 10(b), and so, they must be held to be invalid.

facts.text: Haridas Roy terminated September 18, 1958 after refusing absorption as Assistant.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon his services were terminated by an order dated the 18th September, 1958. In this letter, Roy was told that his case had been carefully considered by the Zonal Committee and he was offered ex-gratia to be absorbed on the administrative side as an Assistant

facts.text: Appeals dismissed, High Court orders confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the orders passed by the High Court are confirmed, and the appeals are dismissed with costs.

issues.text: whether the High Court was in error in holding that the orders of discharge passed respectively against the respondents in these appeals were invalid

anchor.surface_text: On similar facts, the appellants have brought to this Court the other fourteen appeals, and a common question which has been raised by the learned Solicitor-General on behalf of the appellants is that the High Court was in error in holding that the orders of discharge passed respectively against the respondents in these appeals were invalid.

issues.text: what is the effect of this order of appointment

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it appears that after this order was given to Mr. Mukherjee, he began to work as a Field Officer by virtue of his appointment under the relevant Government Order. One of the points which we have to consider in the present appeal is what is the effect of this order of appointment ?

issues.text: whether the power to terminate services conferred by paragraph 4(h) of the circular is independent of clause 10 of the Order

anchor.surface_text: The respondents contention is that the termination of their services can be brought about only under clause 10 a or 10 b of the Order, and since it has not been so brought about, the impugned orders are invalid. On the other hand, the learned Solicitor-General contends that the power to terminate services conferred by paragraph 4 h of the circular is independent of clause 10 of the Order,

issues.text: whether the impugned orders terminating the services comply with clause 10(a) or 10(b) of the Order

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that before terminating the services of the respective respondents in the group of appeals before us, no enquiry has been held and no opportunity has been given to the said officers as required by clause 10 a of the Order. It is also common ground that the impugned termination of their services has not been effected under clause 10 b of the Order.

issues.text: whether relief can be granted on the alternative basis of non-compliance with clause 10 despite claim under Art. 311(2)

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in the present proceedings the respondents had claimed relief under Art. 311 2 of the Constitution and had in their writ petitions challenged the validity of the Order and the Regulations. That, however, does not dis-entitle the respondents from claiming the same relief on the alternative basis that though the Order and the Regulations may be valid,

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that the provisions contained in s. 11 2  of the Act are paramount and would override any contrary provisions contained in the Order or the Regulations.

arguments.claim: Regulations under s.49 must not be inconsistent with Act and Order

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Order in law partake of the character of the rules framed under s. 48 of the Act. Thus next to the provisions of s. 11 2  of the Act will stand the provisions of the Order.

arguments.claim: Clause 10 provides the only manner for termination of Development Officers' services

anchor.surface_text: Clause 10 is relevant for our purpose and must be set out in full Penalties and termination of service In case of unsatisfactory performance of duties by a Development Officer or

holdings.text: The impugned orders terminating the services of the respective respondents have not been passed in accordance either with clause 10(a) or 10(b), and so, they must be held to be invalid.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already seen, it is common ground that the impugned orders terminating the services of the respective respondents have not been passed in accordance either with clause 10(a) or 10(b), and so, they must be held to be invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground no enquiry under 10(a) or prior approval under 10(b); termination must comply with clause 10 of the Order.

holdings.text: Paragraph 4(h) of the circular does not confer authority to terminate services independently of clause 10 of the Order; such interpretation would be inconsistent and invalid; instead, termination under 4(h) must follow clause 10 procedure.

anchor.surface_text: If the said portion of paragraph 4 h  is interpreted to mean that it confers on the Corporation an authority to terminate the services of the Development Officer independently of clause 10 of the Order, it would be inconsistent with the said clause and would, therefore, be invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction reconciles para 4(h) with clause 10; para 4(h) identifies cases liable for termination, but procedure governed by clause 10.

holdings.text: The provisions contained in s. 11(2) of the Act are paramount and would override any contrary provisions contained in the Order or the Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that the provisions contained in s. 11 2  of the Act are paramount and would override any contrary provisions contained in the Order or the Regulations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory hierarchy: Act overrides subordinate Order and Regulations made under it.

holdings.text: The provisions of the Order partake of the character of rules framed under s. 48 of the Act; next to s.11(2), Order prevails over Regulations under s.49 which cannot be inconsistent with Act or Order.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions of s. 11 2 , the provisions of the Order will prevail, because the Order has been issued by the Central Government by virtue of the powers conferred on it by s. 11 2  itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal character: Order issued under s.11(2) equivalent to rules under s.48; Regulations subordinate and must conform.

holdings.text: Respondents not disentitled from relief on alternative basis that impugned orders invalid for non-compliance with clause 10 of the Order, despite claiming under Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in the present proceedings the respondents had claimed relief under Art. 311 2  of the Constitution and had in their writ petitions challenged the validity of the Order and the Regulations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ proceedings allow alternative grounds for same relief.

holdings.text: The order terminating Haridas Roy's services is invalid; not justified under para 4(h) or s.11(2); absorption offer as Assistant not authorized.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Same as other cases; para 4(h) only for remuneration in Development Officer category; refusal of reduced pay could trigger s.11(2) but termination requires clause 10.

holdings.text: Employees of insurers became employees of Corporation under s.11(1) holding office by same tenure, remuneration, terms until terminated or altered.

anchor.surface_text: Every whole-time employee of an insurer whose controlled business has been transferred to and vested in the Corporation and who was employed by the insurer wholly or mainly in connection with his controlled business immediately before the appointed day shall,

holdings.text: Central Government under s.11(2) may alter terms notwithstanding s.11(1) or other laws; if alteration not acceptable, Corporation may terminate with 3 months remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: Where the Central Government is satisfied that for the purpose of securing uniformity in the scales of remuneration and the other terms and conditions of service applicable, to employees or any class of them is called for, the Central Government may,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory power with non-obstante clause and termination option.

holdings.text: The orders passed by the High Court are confirmed, and the appeals are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the orders passed by the High Court are confirmed, and the appeals are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All terminations invalid; High Court correctly quashed orders.
